docs.lead_paragraph: As many Americans make New Year's resolutions focusing on weight loss and healthier eating habits, a new study released today highlights a growing tendency to disregard expert dietary advice. In a random survey of 1,750 adults, 70 percent maintained that Americans were obsessed with the subject of fat in their diets and agreed that the government should not tell people what to eat.

headline.main: Many Americans Fed Up With Diet Advice

docs.abstract: Seventy percent of adult respondents in survey led by Ruth E Patterson say Americans are obsessed with subject of dietary fat and agree that government should not tell people what to eat; 25 percent find eating low-fat foods less enjoyable; 40 percent are tired of hearing about what foods they should or should not eat; men ages 18 to 35, the elderly and poorer people especially reject dietary admonitions (M)
docs.snippet: As many Americans make New Year's resolutions focusing on weight loss and healthier eating habits, a new study released today highlights a growing tendency to disregard expert dietary advice.    In a random survey of 1,750 adults, 70 percent...

docs.lead_paragraph: Let's start the real new millennium with some good news: Americans are eating more fruits and vegetables than they did a decade ago. Nearly half now meet the recommendations of the National Cancer Institute, Department of Agriculture and other health agencies to consume at least five servings a day of fruits and vegetables. But before becoming complacent about the healthfulness of your diet, there is some bad news: the kinds of produce most commonly consumed are not necessarily those that are most likely to be health-protective.

headline.main: Eat Your Vegetables! But Choose Wisely

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on health benefits of eating fruits and vegetables; notes most popular produce are not necessarily those most likely to be health-protective; table; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Let's start the real new millennium with some good news: Americans are eating more fruits and vegetables than they did a decade ago. Nearly half now meet the recommendations of the National Cancer Institute, Department of Agriculture and other health...

docs.lead_paragraph: The aspiring doctors weren't quite sure what to make of the man in the floppy black hat, an imposing figure whose craggy face and gnarled hands betrayed hard work and hardship despite his elegant clothes. How old was this guy anyway? What was his occupation? Was he accomplished or disappointed? Standing before the life-size portrait in the West Gallery of the Frick Collection, the medical students even found it tricky to discern the subject's beret from the painting's dark background, though several noted his unusually long arms.

headline.main: By Observing Art, Med Students Learn Art of Observation

docs.abstract: Frick Collection and Weill Cornell Medical College offer pilot program of art observation for medical students; program is aimed at spurring students to notice and interpret visual health cues in human face and body; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The aspiring doctors weren't quite sure what to make of the man in the floppy black hat, an imposing figure whose craggy face and gnarled hands betrayed hard work and hardship despite his elegant clothes.    How old was this guy anyway? What was his...

keywords.value: WEILL MEDICAL COLLEGE OF CORNELL UNIVERSITY

docs.lead_paragraph: Mammography is arguably the best method there is for detecting breast cancer early and for reducing the number of deaths from the disease. Given that fact, its imperfect record is one of the great frustrations of cancer professionals and women alike. So it is no surprise that the Food and Drug Administration's approval of the first digital mammography unit early this year was met with much hope and enthusiasm.

headline.main: An Upgrade That Matters? Mammography's Next Step Is Assessed

docs.abstract: Digital mammography, which converts X-ray used during traditional mammography into computer screen image, holds promise of improved diagnosis of breast cancer; experts warn expected benefits have yet to be proven in studies; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Mammography is arguably the best method there is for detecting breast cancer early and for reducing the number of deaths from the disease. Given that fact, its imperfect record is one of the great frustrations of cancer professionals and women alike....

docs.lead_paragraph: Could the reason Americans eat so few health-protective fruits and vegetables be that the very same plant chemicals that are deemed healthful do not taste very good? Dr. Adam Drewnowski and his colleague Carmen Gomez-Carneros at the University of Washington School of Public Health report in a recent issue of the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition that most, if not all, of the biologically active compounds in fruits and vegetables that appear to lower the risk of cancer and heart disease are ''bitter, acrid or astringent and therefore aversive to the consumer.''
docs.abstract: Dr Adam Drewnowski and Carmen Gomez-Carneros report most of biologically active compounds in fruits and vegetables that apparently offer health benefits are also 'bitter, acrid, or astringent'; note plants develop unpleasant-tasting compounds to repel insects, other predators and invading micro-organisms (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Here is the problem, as Dr. Linda Bartoshuk sees it: Say that two men, call them Richard and John, are both suffering from depression, and a researcher wants to find out if a particular medication will offer them relief. Asked to rate the intensity of his depression on a scale of 1 to 10, Richard selects a 6. John, given the same rating scale, also picks a 6. But does he feel the same degree of depression as John?

headline.main: Researcher Challenges a Host of Psychological Studies

docs.abstract: Dr Linda Bartoshuk says psychological studies that use common measurement technique, rating scale, to compare different people's subjective experiences often fail to take into account relative nature of subject's responses; says mistake, in some cases, can completely invalidate studies' findings; graph; photo (M)
